intro: Humboltia racemiflora, commonly known as the coastal morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the western coast of the United States. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its heliotropic flowers that open in the morning and close in the evening. The plant typically grows along rocky shores and sandy beaches, where it thrives in coastal environments. Its vines can reach lengths of up to 10 meters, and it produces small, trumpet-shaped flowers in shades of blue and purple. Humboltia racemiflora is adapted to salt spray and strong winds, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
